Description: Body sherd (mended from six fragments) of Chian black-figured Grand Style pottery kylix; white slip; interior: black zone outside tondo which is bounded by black band with frieze of pendant pomegranates; in tondo, black figure siren to left (head with added red in hair and on eye, curlicue, wing, chest with maeander pattern and part of body scales remaining); exterior: band of rising rays on mid-wall between narrow and wide brown and red bands; below, band of tongues above further brown and red bands.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to Williams, the kylix is by the same painter as British Museum 1886,0401.1283, whom he has dubbed the Sirens Painter. The Laconian influences on this kylix are clear from from a number of features. The Laconian black-figured kylix (for instance, see British Museum 1888,0601.523 from Naukratis and 1854,0810.4 from Sicyon) is a well known vase shape which is not typically found in the Chian repertoire. The exterior decoration consisting of concentric bands, tongues and rising rays on the sherd are typical of Laconian kylixes. Finally, the pomegranate pattern around the tondo is the 'signature' pattern of the Laconian artist known as the Boread Painter. According to Lemos, there is also a horizontal handle palmette on the exterior of the kylix, but one is not visible, nor is it mentioned in any of the other publications. The handle palmette is another typical Laconian feature.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 154-6, p. 158-60, p. 323, no. 1458, pl. 193)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p. 130, fig. 14)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 83, no. 33, pl. V)
Walter-Karydi 1973 / Samische Gefässe des 6. Jahrhunderts vor Christi: Landschaftsstile ostgriechischer Gefässe (p. 141, no. 836, pl. 99)
Stibbe 1972 / Lakonische Vasenmaler des sechsten Jahrhunderts v. Chr. (89 note 1, pl. 60, no. 2-3)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1902) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
